SetType.SetTypeDescription: The Standard codeset type is used for regular coding such as keywording or data-extraction. This codeset type can contain multiple levels of child codes but cannot contain the special code types "Include" and "Exclude".

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Select if these appear in the intervention, even if they are not a major component. Highlight text and provide detail in info box.
AttributesList.AttributeName: Which teaching approaches appear in the intervention?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Refers to strategies which enable pupils to take ownership of a task. This could be within the planning, monitoring or evaluating of a task.

Refers to talk which encourages augmentation, reasoning, questioning, sharing thoughts, building on others ideas etc. This can be as part of collaborative learning in group work, in pairs, or between teacher and pupil.
Planning work refers to strategies that are undertaken prior to a task to aid success.

Reflecting on learning refers to strategies that encourage reflection on a learning goal or task. It can be self reflection or related to a judgement of learning (pupils' ability to accurately report how well they did on a task) .

Modelling thinking aloud refers to teachers verbalising their thought process to scaffold learning to pupils. This might involve breaking down the steps to a task or talking through deliberate mistakes and corrections.
A different teaching strategy appears. Please provide info and highlight text.

AttributesList.AttributeName: Which teaching approaches are a major element?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Refers to strategies which enable pupils to take ownership of a task. This could be within the planning, monitoring or evaluating of a task.

Refers to talk which encourages augmentation, reasoning, questioning, sharing thoughts, building on others ideas etc. This can be as part of collaborative learning in group work, in pairs, or between teacher and pupil.
Planning work refers to strategies that are undertaken prior to a task to aid success.

Reflecting on learning refers to strategies that encourage reflection on a learning goal or task. It can be self reflection or related to a judgement of learning (pupils' ability to accurately report how well they did on a task) .

Modelling thinking aloud refers to teachers verbalising their thought process to scaffold learning to pupils. This might involve breaking down the steps to a task or talking through deliberate mistakes and corrections.
None of the above are major elements.

Select yes if the metacognitive strategy is grounded in a specific learning task or goal. Select no if the intervention is focused on general thinking skills or strategies and does not relate to a specific task .
AttributesList.AttributeName: Is the intervention embedded in a topic or context?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Select yes if the metacognitive strategy is grounded in a specific learning task or goal.
Select no if the intervention is focused on general thinking skills or strategies and does not relate to a specific task .
Defined as ‘a structured and facilitated activity for teachers intended to increase their teaching ability’. Please highlight relevant explanatory text.

AttributesList.AttributeName: If yes, does professional development relate to the following:

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Refers to training for teachers on how to scaffold learning effectively and provide deliberate difficulty to ensure metacognition is necessary and purposeful. Select if training includes this.
Cognitive load theory refers to cognitive science research on not overwhelming a learner. Select if training includes this.
Please highlight relevant text
No professional development provided.

AttributesList.AttributeName: What are pupils doing in the intervention? (Select all applicable)

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Pupils learn the skills needed to speak in an articulate and confident way through instruction or deliberate practice. Activities may include debating, presenting, performing e.g. poems, drama, appreciations in the dining room.

Learning (through explicit instruction or practising) the skills needed to use talk to interact and learn with others effectively, including both speaking and listening. This may include getting students to track the speaker, learning to take turns in 1:1 conversations or during circle time.

Explain how pupils are learning. Pupils use oral language approaches to developing their literacy skills. It may involve pupils reading aloud with a focus on fluency and expression. Activities may include pupils reading aloud with expression and getting teacher feedback, or self-rehearsing sentences aloud before writing them.

Pupils mostly practise active listening skills rather than speaking. They may listen to the teacher, peer or another input (e.g. digital technology or a guest speaker). For example, the teacher might read aloud to a small group.

Pupils develop and explore their thinking through speaking and listening. They may be encouraged to think more deeply or think critically. This can be alone or with others. It could be subject content knowledge or ideas (e.g. for writing). For example, pupils could take part in drama activities to ‘get in character’ before writing in English lessons e.g. conscience alley

Pupils use talk to verbalise their thinking to consolidate and extend it: this supports metacognition (i.e. their own understanding of their learning process). For example, a pupil might verbalise their thought processes during a problem-solving activity.

Pupils connect known/prior content to new content through speaking and listening. It could be in the context of vocabulary instruction or other content. For example, a vocabulary intervention where pupils do semantic mapping.

AttributesList.AttributeName: What is the teacher doing in the intervention? (Select all applicable)

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: An oral language strategy is an approach that uses speaking and listening.
AttributesList.AttributeName: Using one of these oral language strategies to teach (select all applicable):

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Scaffolding to support pupils to participate in speaking and listening e.g. the teacher leads a discussion during story time or provides sentence stems to support verbal contributions.

Teachers model speaking and listening skills where the focus and purpose is the improvement of these skills. This is in contrast to speaking aloud with the purpose of modelling thinking and strategies (see dialogic approaches below). Interventions may do both. For example, the teacher reads a story book aloud, modelling how to read with fluency and expression.

Using talk to develop pupils’ metacognition (i.e. their own understanding of their learning process). This may include questioning and thinking aloud to model strategies. E.g. The teacher makes a lesson interactive by questioning pupils to extend their thinking.
Teachers give pupils feedback on their oral language skills, including speaking and/or listening. E.g. The teacher listens to pupils read aloud and provides feedback on their expression and fluency.
The teacher is focusing on strategy instruction. The oral language strategy being taught uses speaking and/or listening. Please also select the focus of the strategy.
AttributesList.AttributeName: Teaching pupils to apply an oral language strategy (select all applicable)

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: The teacher teaches pupils to apply a strategy that uses speaking and/or listening with the purpose of improving speaking and/or listening skills. E.g. the teacher teaches pupils the strategy of tracking the speaker with their eyes to support active listening in a conversation.

The teacher teaches pupils to apply a strategy that uses speaking and/or listening for the purpose of learning vocabulary. E.g. pupils learn the strategy of saying an unknown word aloud and breaking it down into its components to identify known parts of the word.

The teacher teaches pupils to apply a strategy that uses speaking and/or listening for the purpose of improving reading comprehension. E.g. the teacher teaches pupils to use the strategy of reading a text out loud with expression to support comprehension.

The teacher teaches pupils to apply a strategy that uses speaking and/or listening for the purpose of acquiring skills or knowledge. E.g. the teacher teaches pupils the strategy of discussing what they already know about a science topic to activate prior knowledge and learn new content.
This is not the same as the groupings for the intervention as a whole. An intervention might be delivered to the whole class, but the talk groupings are in pairs.
AttributesList.AttributeName: In what groupings does speaking and listening take place? (Select all applicable)

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Record how many in the group in the info box. This code refers to collaborative group work. Pupils may discuss ideas, teach each other, work together to achieve a shared goal etc

Discussion in pairs
A pupil engages in conversations with one other pupil. This may be for many purposes e.g. to develop their conversation skills, develop their ideas, learn from each other. Includes think-pair-share, partner talk, and peer tutoring approaches, where an 'expert' pupil teaches a non-expert pupil.
The pupil speaks aloud to aid their own thinking processes e.g. talk for writing (to develop ideas or rehearsal of sentences before writing), or rehearsing vocabulary in context aloud.

Pupils interact with a teacher or other adult. This may be for many purposes e.g. to develop their conversation skills, develop their ideas, learn from each other. It includes dialogic approaches, with back-and-forth interactions and questioning.
The talking aspect of the intervention sits with the teacher, while pupils listen e.g. pupils listen as a teacher reads a story aloud or the teacher models talking through their thought processes.
This question is about implementation of the intervention, rather than eligibility. Code yes if intervention delivery happens in the context of the whole class, rather than in small groups.
AttributesList.AttributeName: Does intervention delivery happen in a whole-class setting?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: The intervention is outside of the usual curriculum (either in addition to or replacing usual lessons). It may be optional or compulsory for pupils. E.g. 1: An external speaker is invited to the school to deliver a session on poetry outside the syllabus. E.g. 2: A debating intervention in which pupils discuss controversial topics that are not part of curriculum content.

The intervention is delivered within a usual subject lesson or is integrated throughout the curriculum. E.g. it is a new pedagogical approach to teaching the usual content, such as the teacher teaching a new set of strategies to support reading comprehension during English lessons.

AttributesList.AttributeName: If it is embedded within the usual curriculum, in what subject?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Literacy means the usual home language lessons with a focus on reading, writing or vocabulary instruction. For younger children, this may include story time (please tick separately).
An intervention that is embedded across multiple subjects e.g. is applied in maths lessons, literacy lessons and science lessons.

Is the intervention targeted and delivered to a specific group, rather than the whole class? This could be in the classroom, but on a separate table. It could also be outside the classroom, during lessons, or outside of lessons.
AttributesList.AttributeName: Is the intervention delivered to a target group?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Socio-economically disadvantaged pupils i.e. from families with low incomes. The intervention is targeted and delivered to specific students, either in addition to, during or replacing usual lessons. E.g. a drama intervention to develop performance skills is offered to disadvantaged pupils only.

Pupils with low prior attainment, or who are at risk of falling behind. E.g. Low-achieving pupils sit separately in English lessons to participate in a vocabulary intervention, delivered by a teaching assistant.

Includes pupils with high prior attainment, or who have been selected by teachers as in need of challenge. E.g. High-achieving pupils are removed from English lessons to participate in an intervention to develop argumentation, delivered by a teaching assistant.
The intervention is targeted for pupils whose mother tongue is not the usual language of instruction. In English medium schools, this would mean pupils with English as an additional language (EAL).
Not targeted: everyone in the class is eligible to receive the intervention.

What is the main reason that oral language is used in the intervention? This may be different to the purpose of the intervention overall. Try to select one or two, but you can select more if necessary.
AttributesList.AttributeName: What is the purpose of using oral language in the intervention?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Oral language (speaking and/or listening) is used to develop pupils' understanding of their own learning process. The intervention may target pupils' reasoning, problem-solving, recall, critical thinking etc.
Oral language (speaking and/or listening approaches) is used as a tool for collaboration with others.
Oral language (speaking and/or listening) is used so that pupils become more confident and articulate speakers, including for public speaking, debating, performance, articulacy etc.
Oral language strategies (speaking and/or listening approaches) are used with the purpose of pupils acquiring subject knowledge.
Oral language strategies (speaking and/or listening approaches) are used with the purpose of pupils developing their literacy skills (reading and writing)
Oral language strategies (using speaking and/or listening) are used with the purpose of pupils acquiring vocabulary.
Only select if information can't be inferred.
Mark here for second opinion with a question in the info box. This would normally be for a specific code or codes, rather than the whole study.

Professional development is defined as ‘a structured and facilitated activity intended to increase teaching ability’. It does not include provision of manuals in and of themselves. Please highlight relevant explanatory text. If no PD is provided, code as 'no" and do not respond to the the remaining PD questions.
AttributesList.AttributeName: Was PD provided to those delivering the intervention?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: The train-the-trainer model involves training trainers who train those that deliver the intervention. For example, developers train teacher leaders, who in turn train teachers, who then deliver the intervention to pupils. Please highlight relevant text and add details in the Info box.

Select a maximum of two codes depending on the ratio of PD content. For example, if PD was exclusively in-person, code as "Face-to-face" only. if the PD had 1 in-person session and 3 webinars, code as "Online (synchronous)" and "Hybrid". If the PD had 2 in-person sessions and 1 webinar, code as "Face-to-face" and "Hybrid". If the PD contained equal proportions of in-person and online content, code as "Hybrid" only.
Most of the PD was delivered in-person.
Most of the PD was delivered through live online sessions.
Most of the PD was delivered through self-paced online activities (e.g. through watching lecture recordings).
The PD used a combination of in-person and online elements.

Please standardise to hours and parts of hours (e.g. 2.5 hours, 30 hours). Where duration is given in 'weeks', assume a 40 hour working week. Where specified in 'days', assume an 8 hour day. Highlight and add only numeric data in the Info box. If there is no information provided, please write ‘Not specified’ in the Info box.
AttributesList.AttributeName: What was the total duration of the PD?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight and add only numeric data in the Info box. If there is no information provided, please write 'Not specified'.
AttributesList.AttributeName: How many PD/training sessions were delivered?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: PD was provided as an ongoing process throughout the duration of the programme (e.g. coaching, monitoring/observations, self-directed learning).

What is the length in hours of a typical session? When given in 'days', assume 8 hours per day. Add only numeric data in the Info box. If there is no information provided, please write ‘Not specified’.
AttributesList.AttributeName: What was the length of PD sessions?
What was the format of the PD?
Core Components Coding (OLD - DO NOT USE)

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: These approaches involve tailoring or adapting teaching to accommodate the specific needs of pupils or classes.

Tailoring teaching, materials or support to meet the learning needs of pupils 'in the moment', including through the use of technology.
Examples:
•  Adapting level of challenge or task complexity in real time
•  Adjusting level of scaffolding in real time
•  Directly addressing misconceptions as they arise
•  Matching pupil activities to current level of understanding
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Educators adapting future lesson plans and resources to address learning gaps and specific needs of pupils and classes, on the basis of formative assessment or pupil responses.
Examples:
•  Planning teaching around identified knowledge gaps or misconceptions
•  Planning teaching around identified prior knowledge of pupils
•  Preparing supplementary or extension activities as needed
AttributesList.AttributeName: 1.2 Adapting future lesson plans and materials

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Offering educators various levels or versions of an intervention or programme at the outset to allow tailoring to setting contexts and/or pupil needs.
Examples:
•  Providing settings with a 'menu' of approaches to choose from
•  Providing different 'levels' of an intervention for pupils with different needs or starting points
•  Using a tool or assessment to determine choice of intervention
•  Providing guidance or training on how and when to select different interventions
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Educators providing temporary supports to pupils during the teaching of complex or unfamiliar problems or tasks until they can manage these independently.
Examples:
•  Providing worked examples
•  Modelling or narrating problem solving
•  Providing templates or outlines
•  Providing prompts or cues
•  Leading pupils through practice activities with close supervision (guided practice)
•  Fading support as pupils become more confident and/or competent (e.g. “I do, we do, you do”)
•  Modelling reading strategies for unfamiliar words (e.g. for decoding: sounding out, looking for familiar patterns)
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing additional explicit instruction and support to individual pupils, or small groups of pupils, either outside of normal lessons or in their place.
Examples:
•  Delivering a targeted small group or 1:1 tutoring intervention
•  Using an online tutoring programme
•  Using a computer-assisted or intelligent tutoring platform
•  Facilitating homework clubs or study groups
AttributesList.AttributeName: 1.5 Providing individual or small group tuition

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Requiring pupils to exceed a specific threshold of proficiency or understanding ('mastery') before progressing to more advanced material.
Examples:
•  Setting clear learning objectives or compencies pupils are required to 'master' before moving on
•  Using a diagnostic tool or assessment to determine if pupils have achieved mastery
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Purposefully grouping pupils for subjects, activities or topics in ways that are not fixed.
Examples:
•  Using within-class attainment grouping
•  Grouping pupils in ways besides attainment (e.g. by interests)
•  Providing the opportunity for groups to be reassigned
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.
These approaches involve ongoing assessment of pupils’ learning and provision of information to the pupil about their progress or performance relative to learning goals or outcomes.

Using activities that provide educators with information about pupils' level of understanding but do not contribute towards formal evaluations or grades.
Examples:
•  Using in-class verbal questioning to assess understanding
•  Whole-class questioning using mini whiteboards
•  Listening to pupils' explanations
•  Observing pupils complete a task
•  Using a quizzes or 'fill in the blank' exercises to assess pupils' prior knowledge and/or preconceptions
•  Using tests or tools to determine ability, understanding or learning needs before starting teaching a topic
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing opportunities for pupils to engage and respond to feedback they have received, either immediately or at a later timepoint.
Examples:
•  Providing opportunities for pupils to resubmit work or try an activity again following receipt of feedback
•  Implementing a feedback model/cycle
•  Providing dedicated improvement and reflection time (DIRT) or silent improvement time (SIT)
•  Encouraging pupils to develop an action plan following receipt of feedback
AttributesList.AttributeName: 2.2 Providing opportunities to act on feedback

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing pupils feedback on their performance or understanding during, or shortly after completing a task.
Examples:
•  Circulating the class during a task and providing individual feedback
•  Providing verbal praise
•  Verbally correcting mistakes
•  Using 'live marking'
•  Drawing pupils’ attention to the salient features and/or likely outcome of the approach they are using
•  Providing immediate feedback during shared reading (e.g. in pairs)
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing feedback that explicitly tells pupils how to improve their work, answers or performance relative to learning goals, and ensuring pupils understand their feedback.
Examples:
•  Providing personalised feedback (e.g. in books/video/audio/via an online platform)
•  Providing feedback aligned with predetermined success criteria
•  Providing personalised targets/actions in feedback
•  Providing detail on what pupils still need to do to meet learning objectives
•  Attributing success to the use of specific strategies
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

These approaches draw on principles from the field of cognitive science, rooted in understanding how pupils acquire, process and retain information. These include practices designed to strengthen recall and scaffold learning.

Providing low-stakes opportunities for pupils to retrieve previously taught knowledge, with the aim of strengthening recall.
Examples:
•  Playing classroom games that focus on recalling previous learning
•  Using quizzing (e.g, multiple choice, short answer questions) 
•  Using 'fill in the blank' or labelling exercises
•  Using whole-class questioning (e.g. hands up, mini whiteboards, cold calling)
•  Using flashcards
•  Using 'brain dump' exercises
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Prompting pupils to think harder or more deeply, prompting them to explain their reasoning, think critically or elaborate with greater detail in their responses.
Examples:
•  Encouraging pupils to think aloud
•  Encouraging self-explanation in written work
•  Encouraging pupils to persist with a problem independently before offering support
•  Creating cognitive conflict (i.e., introducing ideas that challenge pupils' misconceptions)
•  Using prompts or follow-up questions to encourage elaboration
•  Pausing the reading of a text/story to ask questions and elicit explanations
•  Asking pupils to critically evaluate ideas, information or perspectives
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Creating opportunities that encourage pupils to access their existing knowledge of a topic, or knowledge related to the topic, before introducing new content.
Examples:
•  Encouraging pupils to brainstorm what they know about a topic
•  Asking pupils questions that stimulate prior knowledge of a topic ('pre-questioning')
•  Recapping previously taught relevant content
•  Using props and prompts to activate prior knowledge
•  Teaching pupils how to access and use their existing knowledge to approach new or complex problems
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Using activities that help pupils to create structure and make links within and across topics.  
Examples:
•  Using graphic organisers to provide frameworks for content
•  Providing or asking pupils to create concept maps to show how taught ideas link together
•  Using activities that require pupils to compare and contrast different ideas
•  Using tasks or projects that connect ideas from across different topics
•  Emphasising vocabulary links across subjects and topics to help pupils make connections
•  Using activities that aim to help pupils mentally organise information about concepts (e.g. numbers)
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Using activities that aim to reinforce, review and summarise learning.
Examples:
•  Using end-of-lesson, weekly or monthly reviews
•  Summarising or asking pupils to summarise stories or ideas
•  Using activities that aim to ‘bring together’ everything pupils have learnt about a topic
•  Asking pupils to summarise an idea/topic each another (peer teaching)

When teaching, systematically breaking down complex information into smaller parts or steps so as not to overwhelm pupils’ working memory as they process it.
Examples:
•  Breaking down complex instructions into steps
•  Breaking down words into their component parts
•  Breaking down problems into manageable steps
•  Breaking down texts into smaller sections
•  Using mnemonics (e.g. acronyms, rhymes, songs) to help pupils learn complex information
•  Pre-teaching key vocabulary or ideas before starting new topics
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Using visual aids or manipulatives to help pupils understand and visualise the characteristics and qualities of abstract ideas and processes.
Examples:
•  Encouraging pupils to use counters, coins or apparatus to represent or solve problems
•  Using computer-based simulations
•  Using diagrams, infographics or illustrations
•  Using signs or symbols
•  Using animations
•  Asking pupils to build, draw, visualise or otherwise generate their own representation of a concept or problem
•  Making visually explicit the relationships between numbers, or between number and quantity (e.g. using number bonds)
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Using activities and practices that involve deliberately integrate information from both verbal (words) and visual channels (images).
Examples:
•  Representing information using multiple modalities (e.g. visual and auditory, or text and pictures). For example, providing corresponding images when teaching new vocabulary
• Providing complementary verbal explanations of graphics
• Presenting a problem with both text and picture descriptions
• Using integrated diagrams
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Developing memory and habitual recall through deliberate and structured repetition, so that key facts, concepts or skills become automatic and easily accessible for future learning and application.
Examples:
•  Using choral responding
•  Scheduled practice routines (e.g. daily reading or times tables)
•  Providing opportunities for independent practice (e.g. several sets of problems that require the same strategy to solve)
•  Using repetitive drills to build proficiency in specific skills (e.g. musical scales, sports techniques)
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Implementing practices that allow pupils to transfer or apply their knowledge, skills or behaviours in new or different contexts.
Examples
•  Deliberately creating opportunities to reinforce skills/knowledge/vocabulary throughout the day (i.e. proactive)
•  Seeking out teachable moments to reinforce skills/knowledge/vocabulary as opportunities emerge (i.e. reactive)
•  Providing multiple opportunities for pupils to hear, see and use newly learnt words/sounds
•  Embedding opportunities for specific skill/topic development across different subjects and contexts (e.g., applying maths skills in science)
•  Promoting subject-specific talk or language in different contexts (e.g. maths talk during storybook reading)

Deliberately distributing learning activities or sessions over time, with intervals of unrelated content in-between.
Examples:
•  Revisiting the same topic at planned intervals across the school year
•  Revisiting a topic multiple times within a lesson, itnerspersed with less intense "distractor" activities
•  Exposing pupils to the same vocabulary repeatedly over time
•  Using a spiral curriculum
•  Setting home learning assignments that revisit previously covered content after a delay
AttributesList.AttributeName: 3.11 Spacing content within or between lessons

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Sequencing tasks so that learning material is interspersed with similar but distinct content or activities, usually within the same session, to help pupils learn to differentiate between similar concepts, skills or processes.
Examples:
•  Switching between different types of questions or problems
•  Switching between similar types of concepts during teaching
•  Switching between worked examples and problem solving
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.
These approaches involve pupils learning to communicate effectively through working collaboratively with others and opportunities for high-quality interaction.

Teaching pupils speaking and listening skills and strategies for communicating, collaborating and interacting with others effectively.
Examples:
Teaching and modelling...: 
•  Verbal and/or non-verbal communication strategies 
•  Strategies for working and playing together positively and productively
•  How to express ideas clearly and/or contribute to group discussions
•  How to negotiate or jointly agree on a strategy or goal
•  How to manage conflict or disagreement in group tasks
•  Confident speaking skills (e.g. prosody)
•  How to adapt speaking strategies for different purposes and audiences
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Building pupils’ collaborative skills by creating opportunities for pupils to work or engage in shared play together in order to achieve a specific goal or outcome. 
Examples:
•  Asking pupils to solve a problem or co-create an artifact (e.g. a poster) in pairs or small groups
•  Asking pupils to discuss and generate ideas together
•  Asking pupils to evaluate each others’ work and provide feedback
•  Using activities where pupils apply new knowledge (e.g. vocabulary) together
•  Providing opportunities for pupils to learn from an expert/more skilled peer (peer scaffolding / peer tutoring)
•  Asking pupils to think-pair-share
•  Organising whole-setting challenges or events that present opportunities for pupils to work together
AttributesList.AttributeName: 4.2 Providing opportunities for pupils to collaborate with others

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Creating opportunities for pupils to develop their learning or communication skills through group discussion or performance.
Examples:
•  Providing opportunities for pupils to share their work or ideas with the class
•  Asking pupils to think-pair-share
•  Asking pupils to build on others' contributions in discussions
•  Asking pupils to critically evaluate other's responses in discussions (e.g. as part of a class debate)
• Providing opportunities for pupils to practice public speaking (e.g. debating, presenting, performing)
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Creating conditions for high-quality dialogue between educators and pupils, or between pupils, either in general or within the context of specific subjects.
Examples:
•  Noticing and attending to what a pupil is engaged with
•  Asking open-ended questions
•  Teaching and modelling target vocabulary
•  Prompting pupils to respond in full sentences
•  Actively listening to pupils' responses
•  Verbally and/or non-verbally acknowledging and validating pupil responses
•  Expanding on pupils’ responses
•  Encouraging subject-specific talk or language
•  Providing scaffolds to support high quality talk (e.g. sentence stems/talking frames)
AttributesList.AttributeName: 4.4 Creating conditions for high-quality interaction or talk

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.
These approaches refer to educators and settings working with families to support pupils' learning and wider development.

Providing families with activities or resources to enrich and support the home learning environment.
Examples:
•  Providing home learning materials (e.g. books, toys, games)
•  Providing ideas for home learning activities, including by text or email
•  Signposting to online resources (e.g. links to educational websites or videos relating to what pupils are currently learning)
•  Providing families with activities or prompts linked to topics pupils are learning about
AttributesList.AttributeName: 5.1 Providing families with activities, materials or resources

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Teaching families strategies or techniques that support pupils' learning or wider development.
Examples:
•  Teaching families new knowledge and techniques (e.g. through workshops)
•  Modelling strategies or techniques to families (e.g. through home visits)
•  Providing families with opportunities to practice new techniques
•  Teaching families strategies for strengthening relationships or attachments with children
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Fostering buy-in and/or relationships with families and encouraging active involvement with the school/setting community.
Examples:
•  Organising family events to celebrate pupil achievements or progress
•  Organising family events to raise awareness and celebrate diversity or cultural heritage
•  Providing opportunities for families to become part of the school community or get to know other families
•  Offering families financial incentives for engagement
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Communicating with families about pupil learning, behaviour or development, beyond typical channels such as Parents' Evenings or reports.
Examples:
•  Providing personalised updates or reminders (e.g. via text or an online system)
•  Creating opportunities for families to communicate feedback or ask questions about their children’s learning
•  Including families in planning or decision-making processes
•  Regularly communicating with families about what pupils are learning (e.g. using informational leaflets)
•  Telling families about the importance of a particular topic, approach or initiative
AttributesList.AttributeName: 5.4 Communicating with families about pupil learning

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing individualised support to families tailored to meet the specific needs of the pupil and/or their family.
Examples:
•  Tailoring programmes or support to individual families
•  Visiting families to understand their individual contexts
•  Connecting families with relevant services or networks
•  Providing a uniform or food bank for families
•  Offering financial support or incentives to families
•  Targeting offers of support to identified families
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

These approaches support pupils to purposefully direct their own learning and think about their learning more explicitly. This involves teaching them specific strategies for planning, monitoring, and evaluating their learning and creating opportunities for them to put this into practice.

Explicitly teaching pupils strategies to support their development as independent learners.
Examples:
•  Teaching and modelling strategies for planning work or play
•  Teaching and modelling strategies for evaluating or monitoring learning
•  Making explicit the thought processes of expert learners (e.g. through modelling or providing worked examples of metacognitive processes)
•  Highlighting the importance of learning behaviours (e.g. concentration) for self-directed learning
•  Explaining how and when to use self-directed strategies (e.g. revision strategies)
•  Teaching and modelling comprehension strategies (e.g. predicting, questioning, clarifying) or writing strategies (e.g. drafting, editing, sharing) for independent use
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Encouraging pupils to think about the best ways to approach a task, problem or activity before starting it, either verbally or in writing.
Examples:
•  Presenting pupils with a range of approaches they could use
•  Asking pupils to consider how they could approach a task
•  Asking pupils to consider the potential impact and/or strengths and weaknesses of different approaches
•  Reminding or prompting pupils to remember strategies they have used before and the end results
•  Using pre-writing activities to prepare pupils for writing tasks
AttributesList.AttributeName: 6.2 Supporting pupils to plan their work or play

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Creating opportunities for pupils to evaluate and monitor their understanding, performance, or identify what they could do differently next time.
Examples:
Asking pupils to:
•  Reflect on their level of understanding of a topic (e.g. hands up, red-amber-green ratings)
•  Evaluate how a task went
•  Identify the strategies they used to complete a task and how effective they were
•  Reflect on their strengths, weaknesses and/or barriers to learning
•  Consider what they would do differently next time
•  Set themselves goals or targets and revisit these later to assess progress
•  Monitor their writing (e.g. using a checklist, reading own writing aloud)
AttributesList.AttributeName: 6.3 Providing opportunities to reflect on learning

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Supporting the development of key executive functions (such as working memory, attention and cognitive flexibility) in pupils, including through the use of technology.
Examples:
•  Teaching and modelling cognitive strategies to support executive function (e.g. using repetition as a working memory strategy)
•  Prompting and reminding pupils of cognitive strategies
•  Using games and activities explicitly designed to train executive function (both classroom-based and computer-based)
•  Implementing cognitively challenging physical activity (e.g. martial arts)
AttributesList.AttributeName: 6.4 Supporting executive function skills for learning

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: These approaches promote 'buy-in' from pupils, involving activities or systems that purposefully motivate, inspire or engage.

Establishing clear behavioural expectations for pupils, whether for general classroom conduct or for specific tasks.
Examples:
• Explicitly articulating expectations and consequences for behaviour
• Explicitly articulating or modelling expected learning behaviours
• Praising pupils who model expected behaviours
• Reminding pupils of behavioural expectations and consequences (e.g. visual reminders)
• Enforcing behavioural sanctions and rewards consistently
• Establishing principles into a charter, agreement or mission statement
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Creating a learning environment that encourages all pupils to strive for excellence in their work.
Examples:
•  Clearly communicating high expectations to pupils
•  Using language that promotes challenge and aspiration
•  Encouraging pupils to set ambitious but achievable goals and targets
•  Showcasing exemplary work
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Integrating game elements and principles into activities to promote pupil engagement, including through the use of technology.
Examples:
•  Creating a class competition 
•  Creating 'teams'
•  Creating leaderboards where pupils earn points
•  Renaming tasks (e.g. "mission", "operation", "quest")
•  Using games to introduce or consolidate knowledge
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing pupils with tangible rewards for performance, engagement or effort.
Examples:
•  Providing stamps or stickers
•  Providing achievement certificates
•  Providing free time as a reward
•  Creating a reward 'currency' that pupils can exchange for rewards
•  Implementing an award scheme
•  Holding graduation or celebration events (e.g. a party) to mark achievements of milestones (e.g. completing a programme)
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Connecting content to pupils' real-world contexts and personal experiences when teaching.
Examples:
•  Tailoring activities to pupils' interests
•  Connecting stories to pupils' own experiences
•  Using analogies or metaphors
•  Using concrete examples
•  Relating content to a real-world context or problem
•  Asking pupils to think of real-life applications or examples
•  Communicating the relevance of topics/tasks for future work and life
AttributesList.AttributeName: 7.5 Linking content to everyday lives and experiences

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing extracurricular clubs and activities for pupils for the purposes of raising aspirations, enjoyment, or furthering interests. 
Examples:
•  Creating a lunchtime club or afterschool club
•  Providing opportunities for pupils to try something new outside of normal lessons
•  Facilitating recreational trips, visits or events (e.g. outdoor adventure learning)
•  Providing leisure activities over the summer holidays
•  Establishing a mentoring programme using specialist mentors or coaches (e.g. from industry)
•  Arranging work experience/placements for pupils
•  Arranging for pupils to seek guidance from specialist advisors (e.g. careers counsellor)
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Bringing topics ‘to life’ tor contextualising learning through immersive experiences directly related to the topic being taught.
Examples:
•  Facilitating trips or visits linked to the topic being taught
•  Enabling pupils to work on independent projects to apply specific skills or knowledge (e.g.  extracurricular STEM projects)
•  Recreating a real-life situation (e.g. courtroom)
•  Creating opportunities for pupils to engage in role play related to the topic being taught
•  Creating opportunities to learn about a topic outside of the typical setting (e.g. playground, nature)
•  Using immersive technology (e.g. virtual reality) to bring a concept/place to life
•  Organising real-world demonstrations from professionals (e.g. emergency services)
•  Providing carefully chosen materials and resources that allow pupils to discover and learn about specific concepts (e.g. through play)
•  Providing opportunities for pupils to write their own stories and picturebooks on a topic
AttributesList.AttributeName: 7.7 Creating engaging and memorable learning experiences

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Empowering pupils by providing opportunities for them to make meaningful decisions and exercise agency around their learning.
Examples:
•  Allowing pupils to choose their own projects or reading material
•  Co-designing classroom behaviour rules with pupils
•  Providing opportunities for pupils to provide input on curriculum topics (e.g. through voting)
•  Encouraging pupils to choose their own ways of approaching a task or problem
•  Allowing pupils to choose how they work (e.g. choosing their own groups or seating)
•  Implementing pupil-led initiatives (e.g. student councils)
•  Providing opportunities for pupils to participate in school decision-making processes
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Enabling pupils to solve a problem or answer a question through independent experimentation or investigation.
Examples:
•  Creating opportunities for pupils to learn by developing and testing scientific hypotheses or ideas
•  Asking pupils to research a particular topic independently
•  Posing problems for which pupils do not have ready-made solutions
•  Asking pupils to complete an independent project designed to answer a specific question
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.
These approaches refer to strategies that make use of movement or involve making changes to pupils’ physical environment to support learning.

Pupils using task-relevant physical activity or gesture to support learning (embodied learning/cognition).
Examples:
•  Asking pupils to "act out" words, stories or concepts
•  Asking pupils to enact shapes with their body
•  Providing task-relevant dance or musical activities that use the body
•  Encouraging pupils to use their fingers for counting or mathematical problem solving
•  Encouraging pupils to use their fingers to keep mental track of items
•  Encouraging pupils to use their fingers to trace shapes, letters, diagrams or text
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Creating opportunities in the school day for pupils to engage in general physical (i.e. non-task relevant) activity outside of formal PE lessons.
Examples:
•  Scheduling time in the school day (other than PE) for physical activity
•  Providing 'brain breaks' (e.g. stretches, yoga, dance)
•  Facilitating active classroom games
AttributesList.AttributeName: 8.2 Embedding movement within lessons or the school day

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Educators using non-verbal cues such as hand movements, facial expressions and body language to direct pupils’ attention or support understanding.
Examples:
•  Pointing to key bits of information
•  Using hand movements to mimic actions or demonstrate abstract concepts
•  Using non-verbal gestures to manage classroom behaviour
•  Using hand signs to aid communication
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing free or subsidised food or drink to pupils while they are at the setting.
Examples:
• Providing breakfast for pupils
• Providing milk or hydration for pupils
• Providing snacks to pupils
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Making changes to the physical learning space (e.g. classroom, intervention room) to reduce sensory overload and support learning.
Examples:
•  Minimising distractions (e.g. noise)
•  Optimising light brightness
•  Improving classroom air quality
•  Optimising classroom displays (e.g. ensuring salience of content)
•  Optimising the room layout for learning
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.
These approaches support pupils in learning to understand and manage emotions, set and achieve positive goals, feel and show empathy for others, and establish and maintain positive relationships.

Implementing practices that explicitly focus on building relationships between educators and pupils.
Examples:
•  Providing informal interaction opportunities (e.g. greeting at the door)
•  Providing opportunities for educators and pupils to get to know each other
•  Providing 1:1 opportunities for educators and pupils to catch up outside of lessons
•  Designating a key person for each pupil
•  Implementing restorative practices between educators and pupils
•  Demonstrating acceptance and value of pupil’s unique characteristics
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Implementing practices that explicitly focus on building the relationships between pupils or their sense of belonging to the setting.
Examples
•  Implementing a formal or informal 'buddy' or peer mentoring system
•  Modelling relationship-building practices
•  Explaining the features of positive relationships
•  Implementing restorative practices between pupils
•  Providing opportunities for pupils to get to know or appreciate each other (e.g. circle time)
•  Implementing setting-wide initiatives (e.g. a kindness campaign)
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Intentionally providing pupils with experiences designed to build self-confidence and the ability to bounce back from challenges, either generally or in relation to a specific subject/skill.
Examples:
• Teaching pupils the importance of mistakes and 'having a go'
• Teaching and modelling positive self-talk
• Teaching pupils how to reframe their mindset
• Focusing praise on efforts rather than attainment
• Establishing a mentoring programme with an explicit focus on confidence-building
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Creating opportunities to cultivate positive character traits and values in pupils and encourage a sense of personal responsibility.
Examples:
•  Raising pupils' awareness of social injustices
•  Raising pupils' awareness and value of differences (e.g. neurodiversity) and different perspectives (e.g. cultures)
•  Asking pupils to reflect on their core values and what is important to them
•  Encouraging or supporting pupils to volunteer or fund-raise
•  Encouraging pupils to take responsibility for their actions and choices
•  Praising prosocial behaviours and discouraging antisocial behaviours
•  Creating a scheme or award that encourages social action
•  Facilitating visits to develop an understanding of others and the local community (e.g. local nursing home)
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Teaching and supporting pupils to identify, label and understand emotions in themselves and others.
Examples:
• Teaching pupils how to recognise and express how they are feeling
• Teaching pupils how to interpret their own body cues (e.g. connecting body sensations with emotional state)
• Teaching pupils how to recognise and interpret the emotions of others
• Developing perspective taking skills (e.g. through stories or role play)
• Modelling emotion language 
• Using stories or games to build emotion vocabulary
• Providing opportunities for pupils to express how they are feeling (e.g. feeling charts, 'check ins')
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Teaching and supporting pupils to manage and regulate their emotions and behaviour, including through co-regulation.
Examples:
•  Teaching pupils self-regulation strategies (e.g. turn-taking)
•  Modelling self-regulation strategies
•  Using activities that enable pupils to practice self-regulation strategies (e.g. mindfulness activities)
•  Implementing regulation strategies together with pupils (co-regulation)
•  Prompting and reminding pupils of self-regulation strategies
•  Providing separate spaces for pupils to regulate their emotions or behaviour
•  Providing sensory tools and supports to promote self-regulation (e.g. wobble stools. weighted resources, fidget toys)
AttributesList.AttributeName: 9.6 Supporting self-regulation of emotions and behaviour

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.
These approaches involve deliberate modifications to setting-level systems, structures and processes.

Reducing the pupil-staff ratio for regular teaching activities.

Examples:
•  Reducing the number of pupils being taught in a class or group.
•  Using co-teaching (i.e. multiple educators per class)
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Adjusting the structure (e.g. length, format, timings) of learning opportunities with the aim of providing additional learning time, either through more exposure to teaching or by minimising loss of learning time.
Examples:
•  Extending the school day
•  Providing schooling over the weekend of school holidays
•  Increasing the number of days in the school year or providing year-round schooling
•  Changing the configuration of the timetable to increase learning time (e.g. 'double' lessons to minimise time lost to transitions)
•  Using 'flipped learning' approaches where pupils cover core content outside of lessons, such that in-class time can be spent on teaching more difficult concepts or learning activities represented by other components (e.g. collaborative learning or consolidating knowledge)
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Forming and/or sustaining partnerships or relationships between settings and organisation or services.
Examples:
•  Creating a brokerage service to connect settings with external services (e.g. local authority, NHS, mental health or SEND services)
•  Creating and sustaining partnerships between settings and universities
•  Creating and sustaining partnerships between settings and not-for-profit organisations
AttributesList.AttributeName: 10.3 Supporting partnerships or access to services

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing arrangements that allow teaching staff to vary the timing or location of their work.
Examples:
• Having a flexible working policy
• Providing staff with a personal day allowance
• Allowing staff to complete planning, preparation and assessment off-site
• Allowing staff to work compressed hours or choose their start/finish times
• Providing opportunities for staff to attend meetings online
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Implementing practices aimed at reducing educator workload by automating, streamlining or standardising processes, including through the use of technology.
Examples:
•  Automating administrative tasks
•  Using generative artificial intelligence to produce teaching and learning activities
•  Using adaptive technology to automatically scaffold the level of challenge for individual pupils
•  Using software or applications that provide instant feedback to pupils
•  Using automated quizzing software for retrieval practice
•  Using software that tracks pupil’s learning, progress or engagement (e.g. reading management software)
•  Using software to share information with families or to automate communications with families
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.
These approaches involve providing professional development opportunities for educators, through provision of training or support, or by promoting collaboration.

Delivering training to educators aligned with the cognitive principles of how we acquire, process and retain information.
Examples:
•  Enabled spaced learning so topics or concepts are encountered multiple times
•  Managing cognitive load by focussing only on the most relevant content
•  Employ dual coding (i.e. combining the use of verbal and visual information)
•  Activating prior knowledge
•  Using retrieval practice opportunities (e.g. quizzing)
•  Providing reviews or recaps to consolidate content
AttributesList.AttributeName: 11.1 Implementing principles of cognitive science when training educators

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing educator training content that presents evidence from credible sources to increase buy-in.
Examples:
•  Supporting claims with robust research
•  Using an expert educator or prominent academic to advocate for a particular practice
•  Presenting success stories
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Explaining to educators how and why an approach works, by increasing their understanding of relevant pedagogical or subject-specific theory.
Examples:
•  Teaching the theory underpinning a particular approach
•  Providing educators with knowledge and theories related to their subject
•  Teaching theories related to how pupils learn

Modelling the use of target strategies or techniques to demonstrate how an approach should be implemented to educators.
Examples:
•  Providing live demonstrations
•  Providing demonstration videos
•  Providing worked examples or vignettes
•  Describing or demonstrating what good (or bad) implementation looks like
•  Providing opportunities to shadow or observe delivery
AttributesList.AttributeName: 11.4 Modelling strategies and techniques to educators

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing structured opportunities for educators to rehearse a teaching strategy or approach.
Examples:
•  Providing opportunities to practice an approach within a training session (e.g. through role play)
•  Providing opportunities to practice an approach in-between training sessions
•  Providing opportunities for educators or settings to pilot an approach
AttributesList.AttributeName: 11.5 Providing opportunities for educators to rehearse new techniques

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Supporting educators to independently access and use research evidence sources and evidence-based approaches in their setting.
Examples:
•  Creating an evidence brokerage service to match settings or educators with evidence or experts
•  Emphasising the importance of evidence-informed practice/programmes and/or engaging with evidence
•  Providing opportunities or support for educators to search for research evidence sources
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Supporting educators to question and critique the reliability and relevance of research evidence sources.
Examples:
•  Teaching knowledge of research methods and their relative strengths and limitations
•  Explaining the potential bias of different sources of evidence
•  Modelling how to read and critique a piece of research 
•  Modelling how to interpret research and avoid "lethal mutations" in practice 
•  Teaching how to determine the relevance and applicability of evidence for one's own context
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Putting in place a coaching or mentoring system (either as part of a programme or to support implementation of a new approach) in which educators receive targeted, structured, goal-oriented guidance and support.
Examples:
•  Facilitating peer mentoring between educators, either at the same setting or across different settings
•  Providing coaching to educators (e.g. instructional coaching, content-specific coaching)
•  Providing coaching or mentoring to leadership
AttributesList.AttributeName: 11.8 Implementing a coaching or mentoring system for educators

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing structured opportunities for educators to work together for the purpose of professional development.
Examples:
•  Creating professional learning groups (e.g. journal clubs, reading groups), networks or communities of practice
•  Encouraging educators to observe and feedback on each other's teaching (e.g. through professional learning conversations or team-teaching)
•  Creating collaborative partnerships between settings, or enabling settings to lead or mentor other settings
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Supporting professional growth by encouraging educators to reflect on their practice, either as part of training or more generally.
Examples: 
•  Sharing strategies for effective reflective practice 
•  Sharing models or theories of reflective practice
•  Providing opportunities for educators to share and discuss ideas and experiences
•  Encouraging independent self-monitoring and reflection (e.g. using reflective logs or journals)
•  Encouraging teachers to conduct action research
AttributesList.AttributeName: 11.10 Encouraging educators to engage in reflective practice

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.
These approaches involve processes and practices that support educators to implement new interventions or approaches in their setting.

Cultivating setting buy-in by actively engaging and uniting leadership and the wider setting when launching a new approach.
Examples:
• Providing specific training for leaders (e.g. on implementation and/or a specific approach)
• Providing training at the whole-school level
• Providing coaching or mentoring for leaders
• Encouraging educators to cascade learning to the wider setting
• Including wider setting (e.g. leaders, pastoral staff, SENCOs) in training for a specific approach
• Involving governors or families in the launch of a new approach
• Obtaining and using staff views in decision-making around implementation
• Providing whole-setting incentives (e.g. awards or certification) linked to implementation success
• Strengthening communication quality or systems between staff
AttributesList.AttributeName: 12.1 Engaging and uniting the wider setting

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing settings with time, space or resources to support them to prepare, plan and implement new approaches or policies.
Examples:
•  Providing time within training sessions for educators to make an implementation plan for their setting
•  Asking settings or educators to set themselves action plans or goals 
•  Supporting settings to conduct a local assessment or internal audit to identify needs and priorities
•  Providing tools, templates or guidance to help settings prepare for implementation
•  Encouraging settings to develop an implementation plan
•  Providing professional development on implementation
AttributesList.AttributeName: 12.2 Supporting settings to plan for implementation

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing educators with the freedom and autonomy to create, adapt or contextualise the delivery format, materials or instructional content for a particular approach or programme.
Examples:
•  Explaining to what extent approaches or programmes can be modified or adapted without undermining the causal mechanism
•  Providing central resources for educators to adapt or select from
•  Encouraging educators to create their own resources to use
•  Encouraging educators to experiment with different teaching methods
•  Encouraging educators to adapt the sequencing or structure of an intervention
•  Supporting settings to develop tailored approaches
•  Supporting settings to align a new approach with their existing practices or curriculum
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Providing physical, digital, or financial resources of monetary value so that settings can implement the approach or programme without needing to purchase additional materials. 
Examples:
Providing settings with:
•  Access to specialist software or apps
•  Electronic devices (e.g. tablets)
•  Equipment (e.g. manipulatives, storybooks, toys)
•  Financial contributions towards the purchase of programmes or resources (e.g. cash or vouchers)
•  Subsidised costs for a particular programme or resource
•  Financial support to cover staff costs associated with the implementation of an approach or programme
AttributesList.AttributeName: 12.4 Providing settings with resources to support implementation

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Putting in place structured practical or social support mechanisms, outside of training sessions, to help settings implement new programmes or approaches (excludes coaching/mentoring). 
Examples:
•  Designating a delivery lead at a site (e.g. link teacher, champion)
•  Designating a specific trainer or support person throughout delivery
•  Providing regular check-ins, drop-ins or Q&A sessions
•  Providing supportive visits to observe, feedback and support
•  Arranging support for educators or settings via local hubs or organisations
AttributesList.AttributeName: 12.5 Providing practical or social support to settings

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.

Encouraging or supporting settings to monitor and evaluate the implementation of a new approach or programme themselves (to inform leaders' implementation decisions rather than to provide pupil progress information).
Examples:
•  Supporting or encouraging settings to monitor fidelity, acceptability and impact of new approaches (e.g. through data collection)
•  Developing systems for leaders to keep informed on the implementation of a new approach
•  Providing settings with tools, templates or practical guidance for monitoring and evaluation
•  Encouraging settings to reflect on data collected and revisit and refine implementation plans, or providing guidance on how to do so
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Highlight the reference(s) to component and add detail in the info box if necessary.
Explain in the info box.
Additional coding tool for RCS priority strand update 2025

AttributesList.AttributeName: When are reading comprehension strategies taught?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Reading is taught in isolation. No explicit links made between reading comprehension and the curriculum. For example, pupils participate in a reading programme that replaces an elective class.

Explicit links are made between the intervention and the literacy curriculum, or teaching is integrated into literacy learning. For example, a new strategy to support reading comprehension is introduced in the pupils’ usual literacy lessons.

Explicit links are made between the intervention and the wider curriculum, or teaching is integrated into one or more curriculum subject lessons. For example, a new strategy to support reading comprehension is introduced in a curriculum subject lesson (e.g. science).
Please highlight or provide a summary in the info box. A summary is preferred.

AttributesList.AttributeName: Is the intervention delivered to the whole class?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: The intervention is delivered to the whole class, for example, an intervention to support reading comprehension delivered during English lessons.

The intervention is targeted and delivered to specific students, either in addition to, during or replacing usual lessons, for example, low-achieving pupils sit separately in English lessons to participate in a vocabulary intervention, delivered by a teaching assistant.
Please highlight or provide a summary in the info box. A summary is preferred.

AttributesList.AttributeName: What role does background knowledge play in the intervention approach? (select all that apply)

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Text choice is aligned with curriculum content so that pupils have the background knowledge required for comprehension. For example, pupils are learning about bees in science. A text on bees is selected as one of the texts for the intervention.
AttributesList.AttributeName: The text is intentionally aligned with curriculum content

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: The intervention involves building pupils’ knowledge before or alongside reading the text. Pupils acquire new knowledge or experiences e.g. on a school trip, or through pre-teaching of topic-specific vocabulary.
AttributesList.AttributeName: New knowledge is built to support comprehension

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: The intervention involves activating pupils’ prior knowledge to support comprehension. E.g. Pupils discuss the meaning of key vocabulary before reading a passage.

AttributesList.AttributeName: If digital technology is used, what is the practitioner’s role?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: The practitioner doesn’t deliver teaching, but has a role in supervising the digital technology.
AttributesList.AttributeName: Supervising as the digital technology delivers the teaching

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Add text to info box or highlight to explain the role of the practitioner and digital technology.
Is there separate quantitative data (e.g. an effect size) for pupils who are learning in an additional language?
AttributesList.AttributeName: Is there a separate subgroup analysis for students who are learning in an additional language (e.g. EAL)?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: No need to extract quant data, but a page number would be useful.

AttributesList.AttributeName: How are the components of reading comprehension taught? (select all that apply)

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: The individual components of reading comprehension are not explicitly separated or targeted independently. For example, an expert reader (e.g. teacher) models how they think when they are reading aloud.

The component skills of comprehension (e.g. inference, prediction, summarising) are taught in isolation from each other and they are not explicitly integrated with each other at any point. For example, the whole intervention focuses on only one skill (e.g. inference). Or each intervention session focuses on a different skill and there is no description of how they are brought together.
AttributesList.AttributeName: Individual components are taught separately and NOT integrated

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: The component skills of comprehension (e.g. inference, prediction, summarising) are initially taught in isolation from each other, but they are later modelled or practised together. For example, a session involves the explicit, independent teaching of strategies for prediction and inference. The practitioner then models bringing these together at the end of the session.
AttributesList.AttributeName: Individual components are taught separately and integrated

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Select all that apply to capture what the pupils are doing during the intervention sessions. This includes how pupils take part in learning activities and how they record their answers (if they do).
AttributesList.AttributeName: What are the pupils doing during the intervention sessions? (select all that apply)

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Additional coding tool for Phonics strand update 2025
Select the literacy activity or activities that have been used to integrate phonics instruction. Highlight text illustrating how it is integrated with other literacy activities.
AttributesList.AttributeName: Is the phonics instruction integrated with other literacy activities?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Small group reading instruction with students at similar reading levels
Teacher-led writing sessions
This can include word study, decoding/ encoding words, letter-sound correspondence.
Select 'Yes' if the pupil's existing literacy skills are assessed prior to phonics instruction, or if foundational skills necessary for understanding phonics are reviewed or re-taught.
AttributesList.AttributeName: Does the intervention attempt to match new teaching with the child's existing knowledge (e.g. through diagnostics or pre-teaching required skills)?

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Describe factors reported by the authors to be important determinants of intervention effectiveness. Barriers limit the effectiveness of the intervention.
AttributesList.AttributeName: Does the study mention an barriers to the effectiveness of the intervention? If yes, highlight relevant text

AttributesList.AttributeSetDescription: Describe factors reported by the authors to be important determinants of intervention effectiveness. Enablers/ facilitator improve the effectiveness of the intervention.
AttributesList.AttributeName: Does the study mention any enablers/ facilitators to the effectiveness of the intervention? If yes, highlight relevant text
